aws::graph::propositions: # Administrative Information for NTSB Investigation 90419
Thomas Little is the Investigator In Charge (IIC).
Anthony L Wood is a participating person in the investigation.
Anthony L Wood represents the Federal Aviation Administration.
Anthony L Wood is from Riverside, CA.
Jason Kobi is a participating person in the investigation.
Jason Kobi represents the Transport Safety Board of Canada.
Jason Kobi is from Gatineau.
Ivan Santos de Lima is a participating person in the investigation.
Ivan Santos de Lima represents the Centro de Investigacal e Prevencao de Acidentes.
Vittorio Borsi is a participating person in the investigation.
Vittorio Borsi represents ANSV.
Vittorio Borsi is from Rome.
Alessandro Cometa is a participating person in the investigation.
Alessandro Cometa represents ANSV.
Alessandro Cometa is from Rome.
The original publish date of the investigation is January 18, 2017.
The investigation class is Class.
The NTSB did not travel to the scene of this incident.
The investigation docket is available at https://data.ntsb.gov/Docket?ProjectID=90419.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) is an independent federal agency.
The NTSB is charged by Congress with investigating every civil aviation accident in the United States.
The NTSB investigates significant events in other modes of transportation.
The NTSB investigates railroad transportation events.
The NTSB investigates transit transportation events.
The NTSB investigates highway transportation events.
The NTSB investigates marine transportation events.
The NTSB investigates pipeline transportation events.
The NTSB investigates commercial space transportation events.
The NTSB determines the probable causes of the accidents and events it investigates.
The NTSB issues safety recommendations aimed at preventing future occurrences.
The NTSB conducts transportation safety research studies.
The NTSB offers information to family members and survivors for each accident or event it investigates.
The NTSB offers assistance to family members and survivors for each accident or event it investigates.
The NTSB serves as the appellate authority for enforcement actions involving aviation certificates issued by the Federal Aviation Administration.
The NTSB serves as the appellate authority for enforcement actions involving mariner certificates issued by US Coast Guard.
The NTSB adjudicates appeals of civil penalty actions taken by the Federal Aviation Administration.
The NTSB does not assign fault or blame for an accident or incident.
NTSB accident/incident investigations are fact-finding proceedings with no formal issues and no adverse parties.
NTSB investigations are not conducted for the purpose of determining the rights or liabilities of any person.
The regulation regarding NTSB investigations is found in Title 49 Code of Federal Regulations section 831.4.
Assignment of fault or legal liability is not relevant to the NTSB's statutory mission.
The NTSB's statutory mission is to improve transportation safety by investigating accidents and incidents and issuing safety recommendations.

text:
# Administrative Information

## Investigator In Charge (IIC):
Little, Thomas

## Additional Participating Persons:
* Anthony L Wood; Federal Aviation Administration; Riverside, CA
* Jason Kobi; Transport Safety Board of Canada; Gatineau
* Ivan Santos de Lima; Centro de Investigacal e Prevencao de Acidentes
* Vittorio Borsi; ANSV; Rome
* Alessandro Cometa; ANSV; Rome

## Original Publish Date:
January 18, 2017

## Last Revision Date:

## Investigation Class:
Class

## Note:
The NTSB did not travel to the scene of this incident.

## Investigation Docket:
[https://data.ntsb.gov/Docket?ProjectID=90419](https://data.ntsb.gov/Docket?ProjectID=90419)

The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) is an independent federal agency charged by Congress with investigating every civil aviation accident in the United States and significant events in other modes of transportationrailroad, transit, highway, marine, pipeline, and commercial space. We determine the probable causes of the accidents and events we investigate, and issue safety recommendations aimed at preventing future occurrences. In addition, we conduct transportation safety research studies and offer information and other assistance to family members and survivors for each accident or event we investigate. We also serve as the appellate authority for enforcement actions involving aviation and mariner certificates issued by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) and US Coast Guard, and we adjudicate appeals of civil penalty actions taken by the FAA.

The NTSB does not assign fault or blame for an accident or incident; rather, as specified by NTSB regulation, "accident/incident investigations are fact-finding proceedings with no formal issues and no adverse parties  and are not conducted for the purpose of determining the rights or liabilities of any person" (Title 49 Code of Federal Regulations section 831.4). Assignment of fault or legal liability is not relevant to the NTSB's statutory mission to improve transportation safety by investigating accidents and incidents and issuing safety recommendations.
